text: H hi everyone huy hotan here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new Alan
Palomo project world of hassle this is a
brand new album of material from
Mexican-American producer singer
songwriter synthesizer nut Alan Palomo a
guy who's become strangely elusive since
releasing his last full length LP in
2015 Vega International night school
which you would have to look up under
his Old Stage name Neon Indian the
squishy lowii and nostalgic production
on Allen's old music inspired music fans
and critics to label what he was doing
in entirely new genre called chill
wave a short-lived internet music Trend
that you kind of had to be there for and
maybe shouldn't have even happened as it
did lead to a lot of up-and-coming
artists being pigeonholed into a genre
that they didn't even consciously create
but anyway like I said almost 10 years
ago Allan dropped the full length album
Vega International night school and at
that point I felt that was the best
record he had ever come out with since
making a name for himself in music it's
a really creative synth pop album with
some of the best engineering and synth
patches you'll hear on any record and
while it's by no means perfect I do
think it doesn't get enough discussion
in retrospect so listen to it listen to
it listen to it listen to it now it's
unfortunate Allan began to fall off the
radar a little bit in the years since
that album's release though he did start
to Dabble bit in acting in soundtrack
work a spare Neon Indian single in like
2019 it wouldn't be until this year that
he would really start ramping up output
again but now has started doing it under
his own name and kicked things off in a
big way with a single featuring none
other than MTO Marco and this song is
pretty much everything that has defined
Allen's music over the past decade now
the old school Aesthetics the quirky
analog synth tones sweet pop hooks as
well it is pure vintage Bliss that
transports you to another time and
another place again these are
characteristics that are pretty
consistent within Allen's catalog and
every time he returns with a new record
seemingly he gets better at it which I
would say is also the case for World of
hassle a record that may be under
Allen's own name but I don't think he's
ever been more in character looking
really Deb in air on the front cover
with a new suit and sexy mustache and
many of the songs on this record are
linked to Stories character portraits a
vivid portrayals of a setting or place
like the whaling Mall which might be
kind of long- winded as a spoken word
piece at 5 minutes in length it is also
the first track on the record to but I
do appreciate the extra mile Allen goes
on this track to paint a picture of his
younger self lost in the mall and it
becomes his world as a result with nods
to the 9s Payless Shoes Rainforest Cafe
and given how cinematic the sac solos
and wailing lead Melody sound I'm not
surprised to hear that Allen has
recently been working in film which
could also be said of the track miter
which features verses sung in French
from vocalist Flor Ben gige the whole
track sounds like the theme song to a
really campy tongue-and-cheek murder
mystery show set in an old Victorian
house and aired on a local network
affiliate in the late ' 80s it is
playful it is spooky and slightly silly
too and in the two tracks so far on this
record Allen has conjured these very
Niche and specific vintage Vibes and of
course this continues deeper onto the
record whether it's the Myster ious and
Lovick ballad sng in Spanish l madena or
the return of Mickey Milan where Alan is
singing about a pop artist coming back
into the Limelight after some time away
and while there are names and dates and
finer details to this story part of me
wonders if all of that was just kind of
changed around for Allan to tell his own
tale and music in a way plus again
incredibly beautiful old school and
detailed production on this track too
the swirling synth arpeggios the gummy
Bass the atmospheric tones soaring above
it at all not to mention these
theatrical little additions where you
know Allan is like announcing Mickey
Milan we go from here to a very strong
midpoint on the record there's the very
funny stay-at-home DJ which is truly one
for the uh music nerds and collectors
spinning their own records while deep in
a fantasy of I guess exposing others to
uh music there are some funny nods to
talk talk and prefab sprout in the
lyrics as well with calls of go on take
the ox cord set to these dreamy dance
beats we get another Banger on the
record with Club people which is a total
dance Anthem with some warm jumping
baselines and wailing saxophones the
production on this one sounds especially
compressed and Atmospheric like
something coming off an old cassette
tape or a fuzzy AM radio band and of
course I also want to mention the Sultry
and Moody nobody's woman which is set up
by this very epic and passionate
two-minute instrumental intro and makes
for one of the most haunting ballads on
the entire record now closing things up
the last leg of this record I do think
loses some steam Allen does begin to
paint himself into a corner a little bit
with the Retro 80 synth magic and while
I do respect is their nightlife after
death for being as Starry and gorgeous
and spacious and as open as it is drift
into a beautiful deep I think the
following slow burners don't have quite
as much impact whether that be the very
campy Big Night Of Heartache where Allan
kind of tells a story of I suppose like
a date gone kind of wrong with with an
instrumental that sounds kind of like a
soft core porn tropical sex Odyssey
feels like The Vibes and the narrative
in the story are kind of taking
precedent over the song which I would
say is even more so the case for the
island years and then the entire record
finishes off with a pretty anticlimactic
instrumental outro trouble in mind
overall not a bad record from Allen in
fact I think it's quite good and right
up there with Vega International night
school production-wise it is immersive
it is impressive it is movie like but
but sometimes it feels like the
storytelling does kind of like suffocate
the songwriting process a bit as the
tunes kind of suffer at the hand of
emphasizing more a narrative or more of
an old school Vibe I'm feeling a decent
too strong seven on this one transition
